I want to start looking into using a range of different functions with 
neurons in the hope that this will expand NEAT's ability to find 
solutions to particular types of problems, e.g. multiplication and 
vector cross product.

To begin with I want to just distinguish between 'input collector' 
functions and activation functions. A collection function describes how 
the input signals on a neuron are combined, e.g. traditionally we add 
the inputs, but we could do other things such as multiply them. Input 
Collection Function seems like a good term to use, I wonder though if 
there is an existing term I should be using?

Once the inputs have been combined we apply the activation function, and 
again there are all kinds of functions we could use here.

The recent discussion on leaky integrator neurons got me thinking about 
where these would fit into this model. Although they could be described 
as an activation function I think it might be more useful to extend out 
neuron model to include a pre-activation function - and to apply the 
leaky-integrator funtion there.

So the complete model of a neuron would be:

      \  |  /       [Inputs]
        \|/
[Input collection function]
         |
         |
[Pre-activation function]
         |
         |
[Activation function]
         |
   output signal



So that now the shape of the activation function is completely 
independent of how we combine the inputs and whether we use a 
leaky-integrator function.

Some obvious questions then are:

1) What set of functions should we provide NEAT  with at each stage?
[Collection Functions] - Some of these taken from an ealier post by Ian B.
-----------------------
Add
Multiply (can also perform division by using input<1.0)
Logical AND
Logical OR
Variance
Min
Max
Sum squares

[Pre-activation functions]
--------------------------
Linear (do nothing).
Leaky-integrator (probably with fixed parameters)

[Activation functions]
----------------------
Linear
Inverse Linear
Sigmoid
Step

or instead of Inverse Linear, perhaps the inverse of each fn should be 
made available instead?



I'd be interested in other people thoughts on this. Does the neuron 
model make sense? Are there other functions that should be in the above 
lists, or should I drop some of the functions?

Keep in mind that you could (I think) ultimately drop all of the 
functions (except the sigmoid) and still be able to describe all of the 
functions using combinations of a standard neuron. The point is that I 
want to try and take some of the pressure of finding solutions away from 
NEAT's topology searching, because certain functions are hard to 
describe (and therefore discover) using standard neurons - a simple case 
being multiplication.

Colin.
